title: Cinematography Rules Database
description: 50+ professional cinematography principles for emotion-driven visual storytelling

camera_angles.name: Low Angle = Power
camera_angles.principle: Camera positioned below subject's eye level, shooting upward
camera_angles.typical_usage: Introducing antagonists, heroic moments, characters gaining power
camera_angles.technical_notes: 15-45° below eye level. Exaggerate for intimidation. Combine with wide lens for distortion.

camera_angles.name: High Angle = Vulnerability
camera_angles.principle: Camera positioned above subject's eye level, shooting downward
camera_angles.typical_usage: Character realization moments, emotional breakdowns, overwhelming situations
camera_angles.technical_notes: 15-45° above eye level. Extreme high angles (bird's eye) for divine/objective POV.
camera_angles.avoid_when: Building character strength or showing dominance

camera_angles.name: Dutch Angle (Tilted) = Disorientation
camera_angles.typical_usage: Horror, psychological thrillers, character mental instability, world gone wrong
camera_angles.technical_notes: 5-45° tilt. Subtle (5-15°) for unease, extreme (30-45°) for madness. Don't overuse.

camera_angles.name: Eye Level = Neutrality
camera_angles.typical_usage: Dialogue scenes, establishing character relationships, documentary realism
camera_angles.technical_notes: Most common angle. Creates audience-character equality. Versatile baseline.
camera_angles.avoid_when: Need to emphasize power dynamics or psychological states

camera_angles.name: Overhead/Bird's Eye = God's View
camera_angles.typical_usage: Death scenes, moments of destiny, showing character as small in world
camera_angles.technical_notes: Requires crane, drone, or special rigging. Flattens depth. Use sparingly for impact.
camera_angles.avoid_when: Intimate character moments requiring emotional connection

camera_angles.name: Worm's Eye = Extreme Power
camera_angles.principle: Camera on ground level, extreme upward angle
camera_angles.typical_usage: Establishing villains, towering structures, overwhelming forces
camera_angles.technical_notes: More extreme than low angle. Creates dramatic distortion. Use for maximum impact.

camera_movement.name: Static = Stability or Tension
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Calm observation OR building suspense through stillness
camera_movement.typical_usage: Moments of contemplation, horror (stillness before attack), formal compositions
camera_movement.technical_notes: Use tripod or locked-off camera. Let action move through frame. Powerful when combined with moving subjects.
camera_movement.avoid_when: High-energy action or need for dynamic visual flow

camera_movement.name: Pan = Revelation or Connection
camera_movement.typical_usage: Revealing new information, tracking characters, establishing spatial relationships
camera_movement.technical_notes: Speed matters: slow = contemplative, fast = urgent. Whip pans for shock or transition.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Need vertical dimension or intimate close-ups

camera_movement.name: Tilt = Scale or Judgment
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Revealing height/scale, showing judgment or realization
camera_movement.typical_usage: Revealing tall structures, character power shifts, heaven-to-hell metaphors
camera_movement.technical_notes: Tilt up = aspiration/hope, tilt down = judgment/despair. Speed conveys urgency.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Horizontal action or need for lateral movement

camera_movement.name: Dolly In = Intensification
camera_movement.principle: Camera moves physically forward toward subject
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Increasing tension, drawing audience in, intimacy growing
camera_movement.typical_usage: Building suspense, character realization moments, increasing emotional stakes
camera_movement.technical_notes: Different from zoom (perspective changes). Smooth, motorized dolly for professional look. Speed = emotional intensity.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Need to create distance or show environmental context

camera_movement.name: Dolly Out = Isolation or Revelation
camera_movement.principle: Camera moves physically backward away from subject
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Isolation, loss, revealing wider context, emotional distance
camera_movement.typical_usage: Character left alone, revealing character's small place in world, endings
camera_movement.technical_notes: Creates growing emptiness. Combine with subject stillness for maximum isolation effect.

camera_movement.name: Tracking/Trucking = Following or Parallelism
camera_movement.typical_usage: Walking scenes, establishing motion, following characters through environments
camera_movement.technical_notes: Keep subject in consistent frame position. Match speed to action. Dolly track or Steadicam for smoothness.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Static moments or need for direct confrontation

camera_movement.name: Handheld = Realism or Chaos
camera_movement.principle: Camera operator holds camera without stabilization
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Urgency, realism, chaos, subjective POV, documentary feel
camera_movement.typical_usage: Action scenes, chase sequences, found footage, moments of panic
camera_movement.technical_notes: Amount of shake = emotional intensity. Too much becomes distracting. Modern handheld is subtler than 90s.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Formal compositions, quiet moments, or polished aesthetic

camera_movement.name: Steadicam = Fluid Grace
camera_movement.principle: Stabilized handheld allowing smooth movement through complex spaces
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Ghost-like observation, dream state, fluid exploration
camera_movement.typical_usage: Long takes, following characters through buildings, supernatural POV
camera_movement.technical_notes: Allows movement impossible for dolly. Signature of films like The Shining, Goodfellas.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Need for locked-off formality or extreme handheld chaos

camera_movement.name: Crane Up = Ascension or God's View
camera_movement.principle: Camera rises vertically while potentially moving horizontally
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Ascending to heaven, achieving perspective, emotional release
camera_movement.typical_usage: Endings, moments of transcendence, revealing scale of situation
camera_movement.technical_notes: Expensive equipment. Often combined with pull-back. Classic ending shot.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Intimate character moments or maintaining ground-level perspective

camera_movement.name: Crane Down = Descent or Focus
camera_movement.principle: Camera descends vertically while potentially moving horizontally
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Entering scene, focusing on detail, descending into darkness
camera_movement.typical_usage: Opening shots, entering new locations, zooming into character psychology
camera_movement.technical_notes: Creates sense of arrival. Can combine with dolly forward for complex movement.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Need for uplifting or transcendent feeling

camera_movement.name: Zoom In = Sudden Realization
camera_movement.principle: Focal length changes to magnify subject
camera_movement.typical_usage: Horror reveals, character realizations, dramatic punctuation
camera_movement.technical_notes: Different from dolly (perspective stays same). Fast zooms for shock. Generally less cinematic than dolly.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Subtle emotional moments or maintaining realism

camera_movement.name: Whip Pan = Shock or Transition
camera_movement.principle: Extremely fast horizontal pan, blurring motion
camera_movement.emotional_effect: Shock, sudden shift in focus, disorientation, energy
camera_movement.typical_usage: Action sequences, quick reveals, match cuts, transitions
camera_movement.technical_notes: Creates motion blur. Can hide cuts. Popular in modern action and comedy.
camera_movement.avoid_when: Slow, contemplative scenes or maintaining visual clarity

shot_composition.name: Rule of Thirds
shot_composition.principle: Divide frame into 9 equal parts (3x3 grid), place key elements on lines/intersections
shot_composition.emotional_effect: Visual balance, natural eye movement, professional composition
shot_composition.typical_usage: Nearly all shots. Horizon on top or bottom third. Eyes on upper third line.
shot_composition.technical_notes: Most fundamental composition rule. Breaking it should be intentional choice.
shot_composition.avoid_when: Intentionally creating symmetry, discomfort, or formal compositions

shot_composition.name: Headroom and Lead Room
shot_composition.principle: Space above head (headroom) and in direction of gaze/motion (lead room)
shot_composition.typical_usage: All dialogue, any shots with people or moving subjects
shot_composition.technical_notes: Too much headroom = character feels small. Too little = claustrophobic. Lead room creates anticipation.
shot_composition.avoid_when: Intentionally creating claustrophobia or trapping character in frame

shot_composition.name: Symmetry = Formality or Obsession
shot_composition.principle: Perfect or near-perfect bilateral symmetry in composition
shot_composition.typical_usage: Wes Anderson films, Stanley Kubrick, horror, characters with OCD, formal settings
shot_composition.technical_notes: Requires precise framing. Creates striking, memorable images. Use sparingly for impact.

shot_composition.name: Depth of Field Psychology
shot_composition.principle: Shallow DOF isolates subject, deep DOF shows context
shot_composition.emotional_effect: Shallow = intimacy, isolation. Deep = awareness, context, paranoia
shot_composition.typical_usage: Shallow: close-ups, romance. Deep: establishing shots, suspense ("what's in background?")
shot_composition.technical_notes: Wide aperture (f/1.4-f/2.8) = shallow. Narrow (f/8-f/16) = deep. Focal length affects DOF.

shot_composition.name: Foreground/Background Relationship
shot_composition.principle: Use foreground elements to frame, obstruct, or contextualize background action
shot_composition.typical_usage: Characters separated by doors/windows, framing through objects, layered compositions
shot_composition.technical_notes: Creates 3D depth on 2D screen. Can suggest emotional/physical barriers between characters.

shot_composition.name: Negative Space = Isolation
shot_composition.principle: Large empty areas in frame around small subject
shot_composition.typical_usage: Character emotional isolation, vast landscapes, character vs nature/world
shot_composition.technical_notes: Subject should be small in frame. Empty space is intentional, not accidental. Use wide shots.

shot_composition.name: Tight Framing = Claustrophobia
shot_composition.principle: Subject fills frame with minimal space around them
shot_composition.typical_usage: Thriller confined spaces, intense close-ups, trapped characters
shot_composition.technical_notes: Often combined with close-ups. Character head may touch frame edges. Creates visual tension.
shot_composition.avoid_when: Need for breathing room or showing environment

shot_composition.name: Leading Lines
shot_composition.principle: Use lines in environment to direct viewer's eye toward subject
shot_composition.typical_usage: Roads, hallways, rivers, architectural elements leading to character
shot_composition.technical_notes: Lines can be explicit (roads) or implied (eyelines, pointing). Draws eye naturally to subject.
shot_composition.avoid_when: Need for disorientation or equal weight across frame

lighting_principles.name: Three-Point Lighting = Standard
lighting_principles.principle: Key light (main), fill light (shadows), back light (separation)
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Standard for most scenes. Foundation to build from or rebel against.
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Key 45° to side, fill opposite side softer, back light behind subject above. Ratios determine mood.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Need for stylized, harsh, or naturalistic lighting

lighting_principles.name: Rembrandt Lighting = Drama
lighting_principles.principle: Key light at 45° creates triangle of light on shadowed cheek
lighting_principles.emotional_effect: Dramatic, mysterious, classic portrait feel, depth
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Character portraits, serious moments, classic Hollywood feel
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Named after painter Rembrandt. Triangle should be no wider than eye. Key above eye level.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Need for bright, cheerful, or evenly lit scenes

lighting_principles.name: Butterfly Lighting = Glamour
lighting_principles.principle: Key light directly in front and above, creating butterfly shadow under nose
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Beauty shots, old Hollywood glamour, fashion
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Named for butterfly-shaped nose shadow. Directly above camera. Hides wrinkles, emphasizes cheekbones.

lighting_principles.name: Split Lighting = Duality
lighting_principles.principle: Key light at 90° to subject, lighting exactly half of face
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Characters with dual nature, internal conflict, noir films
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Exactly half face in light, half in shadow. Dramatic and bold. Don't overuse.

lighting_principles.name: Loop Lighting = Natural
lighting_principles.principle: Key light slightly to side, creates small shadow loop from nose
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Most common portrait lighting. Natural-looking dialogue scenes.
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Between Rembrandt and Butterfly. Nose shadow should loop but not touch cheek. Very versatile.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Need for extreme drama or stylization

lighting_principles.name: Low Key = Darkness & Mystery
lighting_principles.principle: High contrast, large areas of shadow, minimal fill light
lighting_principles.emotional_effect: Mystery, drama, danger, film noir, suspense
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Lighting ratio 8:1 or higher. Dark tones dominate. Use shadows as design element.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Comedy, romance, or scenes requiring visibility of detail

lighting_principles.name: High Key = Brightness & Openness
lighting_principles.principle: Low contrast, minimal shadows, even overall brightness
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Sitcoms, commercials, romantic comedies, cheerful scenes
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Lighting ratio 2:1 or lower. Bright, airy feel. Minimize shadows. Avoid harsh contrast.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Drama, mystery, or emotional depth required

lighting_principles.name: Chiaroscuro = Extreme Contrast
lighting_principles.principle: Extreme contrast between light and dark, bold shadows
lighting_principles.emotional_effect: Dramatic, theatrical, good vs evil, intense
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Religious scenes, moral dramas, expressionist films, superhero films
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Italian for "light-dark". No fill light. Bold, hard shadows. Very theatrical.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Subtle, naturalistic, or modern realistic aesthetic

lighting_principles.name: Silhouette = Anonymity
lighting_principles.principle: Subject backlit with no front lighting, appearing as dark shape
lighting_principles.emotional_effect: Mystery, anonymity, dramatic reveal setup, universality
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Mystery characters, dramatic entrances, sunset/sunrise scenes, transitions
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Strong backlight, no front fill. Expose for background. Subject becomes pure shape.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Need to show character emotion or facial detail

lighting_principles.name: Practical Lights = Realism
lighting_principles.principle: Visible light sources in frame (lamps, candles, windows) motivate lighting
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Modern naturalistic cinematography, intimate scenes, night interiors
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Actually visible in shot. Real light sources supplemented by film lights matching quality/direction. Adds realism.
lighting_principles.avoid_when: Stylized, theatrical, or when practicals would distract

lighting_principles.name: Color Temperature Psychology
lighting_principles.principle: Warm light (orange/yellow) vs cool light (blue) convey different emotions
lighting_principles.emotional_effect: Warm = comfort, nostalgia, intimacy. Cool = clinical, modern, detached
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Warm: memories, home, sunset. Cool: hospitals, sci-fi, alienation
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Measured in Kelvin. Tungsten (~3200K) = warm. Daylight (~5600K) = neutral. Blue (~7000K+) = cool. Mix temperatures for conflict.

lighting_principles.name: Hard vs Soft Light
lighting_principles.principle: Hard light creates sharp shadows, soft light creates gradual transitions
lighting_principles.emotional_effect: Hard = harsh, dramatic, unforgiving. Soft = gentle, flattering, dreamy
lighting_principles.typical_usage: Hard: thriller, harsh reality, noon sun. Soft: romance, beauty, overcast day
lighting_principles.technical_notes: Size of source relative to subject. Small source = hard. Large source (diffused) = soft.

focal_length_psychology.name: Wide Lens (16-35mm) = Distortion & Space
focal_length_psychology.principle: Exaggerates perspective, depth, and spatial relationships
focal_length_psychology.typical_usage: Establishing shots, action scenes, close-ups with distortion effect
focal_length_psychology.technical_notes: Distorts faces when close. Exaggerates movement toward/away from camera. Deep DOF.
focal_length_psychology.avoid_when: Flattering portraits or need for natural perspective

focal_length_psychology.name: Normal Lens (40-58mm) = Human Eye
focal_length_psychology.typical_usage: Realistic drama, documentary, when you want camera to disappear
focal_length_psychology.technical_notes: ~50mm on full frame = closest to human vision. Versatile, "invisible" choice.
focal_length_psychology.avoid_when: Need for stylization or special effect from lens

focal_length_psychology.name: Portrait Lens (85-135mm) = Flattering Compression
focal_length_psychology.emotional_effect: Beauty, intimacy, focus, classic cinema look
focal_length_psychology.typical_usage: Close-ups, portraits, romantic scenes, important dialogue
focal_length_psychology.technical_notes: 85mm = standard portrait. Flattering to faces. Shallow DOF for separation. Requires more distance from subject.
focal_length_psychology.avoid_when: Need for environmental context or wide coverage

focal_length_psychology.name: Telephoto Lens (200mm+) = Voyeurism & Isolation
focal_length_psychology.principle: Extreme compression, very shallow DOF, distant perspective
focal_length_psychology.typical_usage: Surveillance POV, isolating subjects from background, paparazzi feel
focal_length_psychology.technical_notes: Extreme background compression. Very shallow DOF. Requires significant distance. Heavy/expensive.
focal_length_psychology.avoid_when: Intimate, close interactions or need for environmental awareness

contrast_and_saturation.name: High Contrast = Drama
contrast_and_saturation.principle: Strong difference between brightest and darkest areas
contrast_and_saturation.technical_notes: Lighting ratio 8:1 or higher. Deep blacks, bright highlights. Can lose detail in shadows/highlights.
contrast_and_saturation.avoid_when: Soft, gentle, or documentary realism needed

contrast_and_saturation.name: Low Contrast = Subtlety
contrast_and_saturation.principle: Minimal difference between lights and darks, gray midtones dominate
contrast_and_saturation.emotional_effect: Subtlety, ambiguity, melancholy, modern indie feel
contrast_and_saturation.typical_usage: Art films, sad scenes, overcast day realism, modern drama
contrast_and_saturation.technical_notes: Flatten lighting, reduce shadows. Can feel washed out if not intentional. Common in color grading trends.
contrast_and_saturation.avoid_when: Need for visual punch or dramatic emphasis

contrast_and_saturation.name: High Saturation = Energy
contrast_and_saturation.typical_usage: Music videos, action films, stylized worlds, Wong Kar-wai films
contrast_and_saturation.technical_notes: Boost saturation in grading. Can feel unrealistic if overdone. Trendy look that dates.
contrast_and_saturation.avoid_when: Realism, subtlety, or period accuracy required

contrast_and_saturation.name: Desaturation = Bleakness
contrast_and_saturation.principle: Muted, grayish colors approaching black and white
contrast_and_saturation.typical_usage: War films, post-apocalyptic, depression, flashbacks, sad memories
contrast_and_saturation.technical_notes: Reduce saturation in grading. Can go full black and white for ultimate effect. Shows texture/form.

sources: Cinematography: Theory and Practice by Blain Brown
The Visual Story by Bruce Block
Master Shots Vol. 1-3 by Christopher Kenworthy
In the Blink of an Eye by Walter Murch
metadata.usage_notes: These rules are guidelines, not laws. Breaking them intentionally can create powerful effects. Context and story always take precedence over rules. Combine multiple rules for complex emotional effects.
